It is a sold Crichton book, and a good beach or plane read.<BR>The thing is ... it's not original enough to earn more than 3 stars. Crichton, while not being a great novelist (let's face it, his characters are not very well developed, they are just there, so the plot can move), nearly allways in the past was original. Before Crichton we haven't read about deadly viruses, nearly sentient gorillas (not counting &quot;Planet of the Apes&quot; or several comic-book characters), or dinosaurs in the modern world.<BR>But deadly nanomachines ... well, we even had Mulder and Scully dealing with the problem in one of original X-files novels (&quot;Antibodies&quot;). The fact that the nanotechnology is not a novel idea in books is not, of course, the authors fault, but it makes the scientific aspect of the novel (which allways was one of Crichtons strong points) less interesting.<BR>Also, I found the first part of the novel a bit too long. This is the part of the novel, which shows the life of the mysterious occurances, and the main character wondering about what's going on, etc. It is well written. But let's face it - you've read the back cover, so you allready know the reason behind all this.<BR>That's the problem with many of todays novels, or maybe not novels, but books. Having to sell them, the publishers put too much information on the cover, and sometimes it spoils the experience of reading. I think that when it comes to Crichton or King, the publishers can wet our interest not by giving away plot points, but by surrounding the book in mystery - like the 5th Harry Potter book. If I've approached this book without any information about what i'll find inside, I would've definetly enjoyed it more.
B00005JKC3|4.0|This is a much better movie than I feared it might be. I'll keep this brief. When Bruce Banner gets mad, the movie easily fulfils all hopes. So often computer graphics disappoint in that there is no sense of \\"reality.\\" The action has no weight, and there is no sense of real power. That is not the case here. The special effects folks did an amazing job in conveying the Hulk's sheer size and terrifying strength. When the green giant tangles with the tanks, It really seems like steel is being torn.  And, suffice to say, the &quot;dog fight&quot; scene is literally worth the purchase price (as was Nick Nolte's final raving scene).<br />The Hulk was (and still is) my favorite comic, and I do not feel cheated by this version. But, it must be said, I think Mr. Lee missed something essential in the Hulk myth. What drove the Hulk/Banner character throughout the comic book was an extreme sense of isolation, of being an outsider from the rest of humanity. Bruce Banner was always a man on the outside because of this terrible beast within him, a terrible dark side that could tear loose at any second.  He could never have normal attachments, and he could never lead a normal life. He was just a drifter. Lost. Director Lee went instead with a very modern &quot;dysfunctional family&quot; theme as the source of the Hulk's rage. While it was an interesting take on it, I prefer the more traditional take on the Hulk; i.e. Bruce Banner drifting from town to town with his terrible secret haunting him at every step. This was the aspect that the television series, and original TV movie with Bill Bixby, captured so well. Perhaps we will see more of this in the sequel, as, admittedly, this was kind of an \\"origin\\" movie.<br />Still, there is more to admire in this version than curse. I will buy the DVD.
B0000027RL|5.0|Ten.  What an album.  Where to start? I bought this CD when it was released, having already been a fan of Mother Love Bone.  Not only was I initally impressed that Pearl Jam was not just MLB with a new frontman, continuing in the same vein musically, I was also deeply moved by the awesome weight that the album manages to shift around.<br />Twelve years later, with significant changes in the landscape of popular music, including a metamorphisis of Pearl Jam themselves, the significance of Ten has not dwindled.  It's far from an obscure title, as you'd be hard pressed to find someone that hasn't heard most of the cuts of the record, and probably owns it.  However, many individuals I have spoken with over the years put it away after listening to familiar cuts like 'Evenflow' or 'Jeremy.'  And who hasn't at one point or another either sung themselves, or heard others singing \\"do do do do do de doooo\\" the familiar refrain from 'Black,' or wailing lyrics from 'Alive' (which, consequently might have the one of the best guitar solos in recent popular music, even at approx. two minutes long, it never tires)<br />But take a look past track 6 (Jeremy), and you'll find a whole other side to the album.  Cuts like 'Garden,' 'Deep,' and 'Oceans' captivate the attention of the listener, with soulful vocals, deeply textured guitar tones, and beats that envoke feelings of John Bonham on Zep's 'When the Levee Breaks.'  Fan favorite live anthem 'Porch' doesn't go unnoticed with its raw intensity coupled best with album opener 'Once.'<br />For this listener, however, the gem of the album is its final cut 'Release.'  This seemingly personal piece envokes so much emotion and intensity all while being the most mellow track on the album.  I highly reccomend listening to this song with a good pair of headphones, so to pick up subtle nuances that only enahnce an already great work.<br />So why review an album twelve years after its release, when everyone and their six brothers owns it, hatesit, or thinks it priceless?  First answer: Why not?  Second answer: Ten deserves to be revisited, each time a little 'Deep'er.  This album can truly captivate when listened to in the right circumstances.  Fall into it today.
B0000C9ZLD|5.0|Many people claim that the music on this album is more of the same from The Strokes.  This simply isn't true.  The Strokes have developed a particular sound.  It is this sound comes through in much of their work.  Many other artists have created their own sound, and nobody accuses them of being repetitious.  Can anybody honestly claim that Bruce Springsteen or The Rolling Stones haven't been writing the same song for the past 30 years?  I didn't think so.  But yes, this album contains more distorted vocals and most of the songs have a driving beat energy to them, but these are the things that create The Strokes's sound.<br />Some people will claim that while the album is good, it isn't as good as their first offering \\"Is This It\\".  This simply isn't true.  The songs are more complicated, the lyrics more comprehensible (both from a logical and listening standpoint), and the hooks are 10x better than \\"Is This It\\".  Every song on the album is strong, but \\"The End Has No End\\" and \\"Under Control\\" are masterful. <br />After having put more time into listening to the album I must say that I am very satisfied with Julian's (lead singer) songwriting on this effort.  While there is still a level of complexity to many of the songs, his message in most pieces is clearly available for the listener to decipher.  Some parts dabble less with complexity or subtlety and just get straight to the point such as, \\"I'm not your friend.  I never was.\\"  This seems pretty haunting when you get right down to it.  It is this type of mix that I really enjoy and I feel makes for a great album from a songwriting standpoint.<br />It is also interesting to find that The Strokes have done a nice job of interpreting those artists who came before them in an effort to try and push their own work forward.  For instance by his own admittance Stroke's guitarist Nick Valensi has stated that some of the baselines on the album come straight from various works by The Cure.  There is also a guitar riff in \\"TheEnd has No End\\" that most definitely seems influenced by GnRs \\"Sweet Child O' Mine\\".  The main hook in \\"12:51\\" bears a remarkable similarity to the work by The Cars from almost 20 years ago.  There are those who will say that it is unfortunate that The Strokes have had to resort to using \\"samples\\" just to try and make some sort of semblance of difference from their last album.  I disagree wholeheartedly and believe that instead this gives the listener some familiar tie that will only encourage additional listening and create the opportunity to study the work more intensely and explore the deeper regions of each track.<br />I am a cynical jerk, but this album is so beautiful it makes me want to cry.  It is the best of 2003 w/o doubt.

B000060P79|4.0|Simple Plan's debut CD, &quot;No Pads, No Helmets...Just Balls,&quot; is no punk or even pop-punk venture, but rather a fun and catchy power pop album. The album's title states a lot about the maturity of the songwriters; much of the content is youthful lamenting of heartbreak, loneliness and boredom. Do not buy this CD if you are expecting anything deeper or more enlightening than what is implied by the title! Juvenile content, catchy vocals and upbeat guitar tunes make this CD good for parties and other light-listening ventures. I wouldn't recommend it for anyone seeking enlightenment or salvation, but if a good sing-along fits your fancy, this CD is worth picking up.<br />Simple Plan writes simple music that sounds good even without being overly complex. Their style is similar to that of Blink 182 and its clones. They focus not on depth but on a catchy melody and solid beat, and the songs on this album you will likely find yourself singing for hours. The music captures a certain youthful energy that much of today's music lacks. Simple Plan achieves well what it set out to do, and that was to create a radio-friendly set of fun songs to which the youth of North America could easily relate. I recommend this CD to anyone who does not consider him or herself punk, as this CD is by no means punk, and seeks a fun album. If that's what you want to hear, Simple Plan truly delivers, and you won't be disappointed.

0446677450|3.0|I must admit that I enjoyed reading this book.  The prose is simple but fairly fluid and the financial advice comes off as genuinely enlightening.  As I put the book down I really did feel more capable of becoming rich.  The problem is that I feel the book has some shady morality around the edges which are easy to glaze over.  Are we supposed to simply overlook the fact that &quot;Rich Dad&quot; does everything in his power to keep down the wages of the people working for him?  We are able to sympathize with him because he helps our narrator achieve wild riches, but still, that does not make up for the fact that he has so little compassion for the people upon whom his wealth depends.  &quot;Rich dad&quot; throws in a little bit here and there about charity, but there is obviously something lacking in his concern for his fellow human beings.  <br />The book repeatedly spouts typical conservative doctrine, saying essentially that the poor end up that way because they do not &quot;produce.&quot;  The irony is that the whole point of the book is to assert that the only way to get rich is by owning things (assets which provide income).  <br />If I own a townhouse and sit in my pajamas all day, playing Nintendo gamecube while collecting rent checks and asking my maid for more Nutter Butters, what exactly am I &quot;producing&quot; again?  Or is the point that we should all strive to escape the &quot;rat race&quot; so that we no longer need to &quot;produce&quot; in order to survice?  Isn't that a great goal, to reach a point where we are no longer expected to contribute to society?  Whatever happens to the rest of the 'rats' is up to them, right?  <br />In the end, if you want to get rich I would recommend this book.  I think it would really help.  If you are looking for a coherent, balanced approach to attaining wealth without sacrificing your integrity, this book is going to come up short.  <br />I would be lying if I said I got nothing out of this book.   It was a breezy, interesting read; I just don't feel like reading the rest of the series.  But then again, if the economy keeps going on like this....<br />Kidding!  I'd rather be homeless and starving than treat another human being like merely a machine for making me richer.  But that's just me, another sucker who will probably never get out of the 'rat race.'

B00004XONN|5.0|When this album first came out 3 years ago I read a lot of negetive reviews.  Radiohead had strayed too far from OK Computer.  They had experimented and failed.  They had become self-indulgent and pretentious.  Heeding these warnings, I never bought the album, even though I loved OK Computer and the Bends.  After picking up Amnesiac and Hail to the Thief I finally decided to round out my Radiohead collection with Pablo Honey, and of course, Kid A.  I'm at somewhat of a loss for words.  Kid A is flat out brilliant.  Three years later it still sounds a decade ahead of its time.  The critics and fans who reacted negatively to it were probably just not ready for it.  They wanted what they were used to from Radiohead: big singing, soaring guitars; classic rock for the new millenium.  What they got was an album full of &quot;Climbing up the Walls&quot; on computers.  Sometimes paranoid, sometimes nostalgic, always haunting. <br />The only disappointment here is that Radiohead apparently listened to their critics and never fully explored the path they start on with Kid A.  Sure, Amenesiac and HttT are great albums.  But neither have the dark, fragile beauty that makes Kid A.  I guess what I'm trying to say is this: I've been listening to music for about three quarters of my life, and really loving it for about half. I'd like to think that I've heard a great deal of the popular music of the past decade.  Quite simply, Kid A takes me to a place that no other album ever has.  Take this album, listen to it with an open mind, and let it show you all the things you'd have never seen otherwise.

B00009P1O5|3.0|Neil Young again throws a curve ball by following up his acoustic and country album Hawks &amp; Doves with 1981's thrashing Re.ac.tor.  The album, like its predecessor, was universally panned by the critics upon its release. While the album was definitely thrown together as the last album to fulfill his Warner contract, it captures the raw and trashy energy of Crazy Horse.  The songs are clearly just thrown together with little or no lyrical cohesion, but the pure energy and power of the band makes up for any lack of creativity.  The epitome of this is song \\"T-Bone\\" which repeats the same line about mashed potatoes and t-bones over and  over for nine plus minutes.  But despite the inane lyric, the band's crashing and crunching riffs are mesmerizing.  The album's final song \\"Shots\\" is another standout with a riveting and threatening vibe. B0000C9ZLD|4.0|The Strokes have improved upon their already brilliant sound with &quot;Room On Fire,&quot; and by this I mean that each musician is putting out a lot more technically and musically than we heard the first time around on &quot;Is This It&quot;.  <br />The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is due to the fact that I feel they made one mistake; they used the same mixing and effects on \\"Room On Fire\\" as on \\"Is This It\\" (i.e. - distortion/fuzz effects on Casablancas' vocals; tin-pan sound of the drums on some songs, etc.) giving the final polished product a very similar sound.  I thought that was a really impressive and original idea on the first album, but I was hoping they would go for something different on this one.<br />This mix alone, I think, is what's throwing off a lot of the critics out there saying The Strokes have repeated themselves with \\"Room On Fire.\\"  After really listening to the songs, one finds this not to be true.  In fact, it's obvious The Strokes have grown and evolved quite a bit in the last 2 years, which is really amazing given they've been touring the world this entire time.<br />What stands out the most about this album is the song-writing and thoughtful compositioning of all 11 gems.  They keep it simple, but only in the overall product, for there are many little touches and changes throughout each song; they don't weakly repeat verse-chorus-verse, but slip in some tweaks and switch things up just enough to keep it all interesting.  It is so great to hear the Strokes' music because it rocks you, makes you smile, and sends chills up your spine because of the sheer pleasure and ingeniousness of it all.<br />It's great to hear the guitarists exploring more complicated and interesting riffs/solos, and Fab proves he's one of the most tasteful drummers to come around since Bonham and Ringo (yet he really rocks out at times and shows how capable and tight a drummer he is...i.e. - check out the incredibly quick kick drum on 'The Way It Is').  Even Casablancas is trying different phrasing techniques, reaching more soulful highs, and overall gives us much more feeling and gut.  Last but not least I have to rave about the bassist who creates such a warm foundation to the Strokes' music and fulfills his role in the rhythm section nicely with simple yet well thought-out and complimentary bass lines.<br />The Strokes are a smart band and nowhere is this more evident than with the awesome songwriting and arrangements found in \\"Room On Fire.\\"

076790592X|3.0|Tuesdays With Morrie is a simple book with a simple message for life.  It is a brief novel with an unembellished style of writing, but just the same Morrie is a person whose words<BR>resonate in the mind.  Many people have read Tuesdays With Morrie, and will continue to read it over time.  Each person who reads it will find his/her own meaning in Morrie's revelations on life.  The book is played out like a teacher's lesson plan, and that is exactly how Morrie and the author, Mitch Albom, intended it to be.  The lessons are easy to<BR>understand but important and relevant to all people and areas of life.  These lessons are gentle in tone, and the frightening subject of death is in this way put on easier grounds to read about.  However, the lessons do at times seem to repeat themselves, finding different ways to say the same thing that was said only a chapter before.  This repetitive nature makes the book at times seem all too much like a lesson in school.  And it is often easy to fall asleep in school.  However, heart and soul were put into the creation of this book; parts of both Mitch Albom and his professor Morrie Schwartz reside within its pages.  And for that Tuesdays With Morrie is a commendable read.

B000002H70|5.0|The genius of Robert Smith is that he takes incredibly simple melodic lines, ones that are maybe too simple. By themselves, they'd be almost childish. But he layers them, one after another, until what results is a sensation not unlike wave after wave of water of alternating temperature. On good headphones, the songs on \\"Disintegration\\" allow for multiple levels of complexity. Each layer is opaque, as well; you can hear through each one, and catch a glimpse of another beneath it. <br />This may well be the best Cure album, in terms of execution. Robert Smith has said that what he wants to create are moods; on \\"Disintegration,\\" he creates a dusky, rainy, dimly-lit place filled with moving melodic lines, distorted guitars and propulsive bass. While the lyrics tell the tale of the album's title, the music is tightly-structured. An atmospheric masterpiece.

B00008J4P5|4.0|I missed the boat on the first couple of White Stripes CDs and was fully prepared to hate them when I bought ELEPHANT--talk about a boatload of hype being forced down down your throat by Rolling Stone and every other out-of-touch music rag--but after four straight days of listening to ELEPHANT at top volume, I am here to say that the White Stripes have got it going on.<br />&quot;Seven Nation Army&quot; is getting the airplay, but the whole album rocks. Kind of like Sweet meets Smashing Pumpkins, with Guns &amp; Roses and the Spiders from Mars playing backup. I mean, they ROCK. There is a lot mure THUMP! to the White Stripes than your typical 21st century band; they appreciate big guitars and are a thousand times more creative than anyone else going right now.<br />As far as I'm concerned &quot;Girl, You Have No Faith In Medicine&quot; is thE Rock song of 2003, an absolute ass-kicker with some of the best singing I've heard by a guy on a Rock record since Kurt Cobain fled the scene. Jack White also plays guitar like Mick Ronson, and you can't beat that.<br />The shortcoming of the White Stripes, as with a million other bands, is that they can't be hard and soft on the same LP. The lighter stuff here--and there isn't much--sounds forced, contrived. If the Stones, Beatles, Zep, Who, and other classic Rockers can point to one thing that sets them above most of the other bands that have attempted the crown since then, it is that they could play both sides of the coin--the Stones had &quot;Midnight Rambler&quot; and &quot;Angie,&quot; the Who had &quot;Love Ain't For Keeping&quot; on the same LP as &quot;Won't Get Fooled Again.&quot;<br />Jack White comes really close on &quot;I Want to Be The Boy...&quot;, and Meg White attempts some kind of subtlety on &quot;In the Cold, Cold Night,&quot; but it really just sounds like one of those blank-generation Goth things Concrete Blonde used to do. There comes a point when a singer needs to put across something deeper; when the White Stripes get to that point they will be a truly great band. I suppose the secret may be to keep Meg behind the drum kit while Jack stretches his vocal chops.hite Stripes get to that point they will be a truly great band. I suppose the secret may be to keep Meg behind the drum kit while Jack stretches his vocal chops.

The plot has a real strand and a dreamlike strand. The former are the attempted murder, the accident, and the scenes at Winky's. The latter are ramblings of Camilla's mind as she is trying to make sense of the accident while her memory is partially coming back. She is confused about her identity and sees everything from Diane's perspective. The &quot;coming back&quot; is reflected in her gradual realization that the roles of Diane and Camilla in the &quot;dream&quot; are reversed. Camilla is initially the protege and Diane is in control, but we later find out that it was the other way around: Camilla, the star, used Diane, the commonplace debutante, and then dropped her. In her recollections, Camilla gets to the point where she wakes up in the night and begins to realize it's all wrong somehow. 0446310786|5.0|I was curious how a few years might change the perspective I had on this book from the first time I read it, in grade 10. Indeed, I think I have benefitted from having a more grown-up view to this material, given how much weight it carries, even if the story is told from the point of view of a youth.<br />&quot;To Kill A Mockingbird&quot; tells the story of an Alabama family, the Finch's, who get caught up a racial battle in their small town as Atticus, a father and widower, defends a black man against the charge of rape. The story is told rather wonderfully from the point of view of Scout, a naive and hot-headed young girl with a nose for a fight, who wanders among many stories, from the eccentric Radleys, to playground fights, to wondering why her father continues to defend that man everyone seems so intent on lynching.<br />&quot;To Kill A Mockingbird&quot; is a wonderful story. It's sweet and poignant and principled without ever being schmaltzy or loaded with sentiment. Among the strongest points, in my opinion, are the little conversations Atticus has with others explaining why he's doing what he's doing, the court sequences, and the subplot with Arthur Radley. There is a pervasive theme of not judging others before getting to know them which is a lasting, timeless message.<br />Recommended to everyone.<br />Matthew D. Johnston

B00000HYXB|4.0|This being the 2nd album I've purchased from BG after Night at the Opera, I definitely thought that while it didn't match up to NATO, it still faired very well on its own. I also heard that this is the first album BG truly went full on in their new direction of music; by that I mean that this has more of an epic fantasy harmonic sound and less of the thrash power metal influence (like on the Somewhere Far Beyond album, which I'm still in the middle of listening to so i'll put up a review soon). <BR>This is a concept record based on one of JRR Tolkiens novels (i forget the name) so every few tracks there is an interlude of dialouge or sound effects which progress the story further as do the song lyrics. A very creative idea and BG pulls it off very well. <BR>Anyways, on to the music. I thought the majority of songs on this were definitely very good, but just didn't have that magic that made NATO so amazing. I guess it might've taken BG a little more time to really master their new sound. There isn't one BAD song on the album, although every now and then you might find yourself skipping through a few, but just a few. It could be due to some songs which feature verses that drag at few moments and a song or two that don't sound too inspirational, but what I've learned about BG thus far is that you CANNOT just listen to it once and judge by that. Their music just has so much to pick out and discover you really need at least 2 or 3 listens to know what you're talking about. What I love most about these guys are they way they sing, mostly the chorus's; they layer voices upon each other to give this choir effect that just makes each song so epic and inspirational, only BG could create such spendid harmony. I was deciding for a little while whether to give this 3.5 or 4 stars, but I went with 4 just because this IS Blind Guardian and they are one of the best power metal bands in the world.<BR>Overall, I might just have been spoiled by NATO and was just expecting something equally as good, which could by why I'm not drueling over this as everyone else on this webpage is. So this just comes off at me as just another good album, but nothing extravagant. I definitely recommend a purchase but a higher recommendation must go to Night at the Opera. I would like to start listening to some old BG just to contrast the different styles of music.

B00005JLYW|3.0|I enjoyed the first Charlie's Angels movie.  It had some good laughs and the fight sequences were so well done, it didn't matter that the plot was non-existant.  Unfortunately, everything that worked in the first movie is hardly used in &quot;Charlie's Angels - Full Throttle&quot;<br />   The biggest problem is Demi Moore... or rather, THE COMPLETE LACK OF DEMI MOORE!!  After months of advertising this movie as Demi's big comeback and hyping how Demi would play an Angel gone bad, Demi only appears for about 7 minutes of screen time.  Despite that it was told in advance that Demi was the villain, the movie is played as a whodunit, where Demi doesn't even appear until towards the end (except for a brief cameo on the beach).  Even worse, her character is poorly written, and the interesting idea of an &quot;Evil Angel&quot; is completely misused.  The only saving grace is Demi Moore herself, who is such a great actress, her performance alone makes you care about her and distracts you from how awful her dialogue is. <br />   Another baffling decision is the lack of martial arts sequences.  While the first movie was packed with great Angel fighting, this movie only has two fight scenes.  One in a warehouse that is shot rather poorly and nowhere near as good as what we saw in the first movie.  The second one is at the end, and ends way too quickly.  Instead of fight sequences, this time the director went with vehicle chases instead, which are not well-filmed or exciting at all.  (A certain dirtbike sequence especially seems to drag on forever.)<br />   Also, the movie is stuffed with lame subplots.  If you think it's not at all funny when Alex's (Lucy Lui) father (John Cleese) thinks his daughter is working as a prostitute, just wait for the almost sickening moment when the father APPROVES of his daughter being a prostitute... &quot;as long as it makes her happy&quot;.  Natalie (Cameron Diaz) doesn't fare much better, with a drawn-out subplot involving her boyfriend that fizzles to a unsatisfying ending.  Instead of going off in these directions, the movie should have used this time to delve more into Madison Lee's (Demi Moore) character.  And don't get me started on Bernie Mac, who's talent is wasted as much in this movie as Bill Murray's was in the first one.  Speaking of underused characters, why is The Thin Man (Crispin Glover) even in this movie???  The Thin Man has absolutely nothing to do with the main plot, and after being a villain in &quot;Charlie's Angels&quot;, now he's suddenly a good guy.  It feels as if the Thin Man was only thrown in for the audience to go, &quot;Cool, that's the guy from the first movie&quot;!   Only Dylan (Drew Barrymore) is spared, as her subplot involving an abusive ex-boyfriend is effective enough to give her more depth<br />   Still, the movie isn't a total waste.  The acting is actually very good.  Demi Moore wasn't given much screen time but made the most of what she had to work with.  Also, all three angels were well-played, especially Drew Barrymore, who I truly think is one of the most under-rated actresses in Hollywood.  Drew makes you feel for her character.  Justin Theroux also comes through with a truly frighting performance as Drew's violent ex.  And for every 10 jokes that don't work, there is one that actually does.  So if you lower your expectations enough, you just may find yourself enjoying this movie...
B000067CPX|5.0|If you want your favorite band to record the same album over and over for 20 years, then you are probably narrow-minded and like being bored. But if you appreciate artistry and talent, and applaud your favorite band when they reach out a little, mature and create something beautiful, then this is the album for you. Just because something is well-crafted and harmonic, full of feeling and introspective, does not mean that they are stupid sell-outs. I am a different person than I was 20 years ago (when I used to listen to heavy metal), and I assume the Chili Peppers are different as well. Tastes change, people mature, and they have different things to say than they did when they were 20. This is what is happening with the Peppers, and I'm glad they're sharing it with us.

B000002LAC|5.0|If ever there was perfection in ensemble vocals, it is in the recording TRIO, which finds Emmylou Harris, Dolly Parton, and Linda Ronstadt throwing off the shackles of stardom and creating an overall sound that completely transcends their individual sounds.  On this recording, decisions have been made more on the basis of vocal suitability rather than on star power, with the opening \\"The Pain of Loving You\\" a case in point.  Originally written by Dolly Parton and Porter Wagner, this would seem an obvious selection for a Parton lead vocal--but here the lead is supplied by Emmylou Harris, with Parton and Ronstadt providing flawlessly blended backups that avoid overshadowing Harris' less authoritative singing style.<br /><br />Throughout the recording, the artists play a sort of musical round robin, each taking the lead in turn and each serving the other vocalists with perfectly placed support--with no one artist overshadowing the other, all three speaking with the same musical intent.  It is a truly remarkable accomplishment made all the more so through its complete simplicity: there are no complex vocal arrangements, no fussy instrumentals, no studio tricks.  This is musicianship pure and simple and flawless in execution.<br /><br />After a memorable \\"Making Plans,\\" on which Parton assumes the lead, the ladies move into what is possibly their single most remarkable cut: a country-tinged version of the memorable 1950s pop hit \\"To Know Him Is To Love Him,\\" in which their voices blend and merge to such a degree that it becomes impossible to say which vocalist has assumed the dominate role in the production.  Linda Ronstadt comes to the fore with the 1930s Jimmy Rogers tune \\"Hobo's Meditation\\" and a remarkably powerful \\"Telling Me Lies\\" and \\"I've Had Enough;\\" Parton provides understated and lovely leads on the self-authored \\"Wildflowers,\\" the slightly bluesy \\"These Memories,\\" and the traditional \\"Rosewood Casket;\\" and Emmylou Harris gives a remarkable beautiful lead on the haunting \\"My Dear Companion.\\"<br /><br />While it is extremely difficult to select a favorite from this recording, if pressed I would give my favorite as the closing \\"Farther Along,\\" a traditional country gospel tune that features each of the ladies in turn to truly remarkable effect.  But it is all good.  TRIO is goose-flesh music: so perfectly done that each selection in turn makes the hair stand on the back of your neck.  You'll not find finer music this side of heaven, and if the angels really do sing in paradise, this is the sound they make.  A truly rapturous, miraculous recording that deserves much greater recognition than it has to date received; strongly recommended.<br /><br />GFT, Amazon ReviewerDear Companion.\\"    While it is extremely difficult to select a favorite from this recording, if pressed I would give my favorite as the closing \\"Farther Along,\\" a traditional country gospel tune that features each of the ladies in turn to truly remarkable effect.  But it is all good.  TRIO is goose-flesh music: so perfectly done that each selection in turn makes the hair stand on the back of your neck.  You'll not find finer music this side of heaven, and if the angels really do sing in paradise, this is the sound they make.  A truly rapturous, miraculous recording that deserves much greater recognition than it has to date received; strongly recommended.    GFT, Amazon Reviewer
B00005YUNY|4.0|These guys are clearly awesome, but this DVD is only &quot;very good,&quot; as opposed to &quot;great!&quot;<br />The song selection could be better, and the 5.1 seperation is not all it could be. B0000524CY|5.0|This is a film that goes way beyond the horror genre for which  it has been labeled with so many other monster movie offerings.  It is an exploration of faith, a complex struggle of good versus evil that stems from the conflicts that are present in each of our lives, combined with a theology lesson and the belief in something greater than ourselves.  Ultimately, it is an exploration of the worst kind of horror, the horror that exists in the belief that for every good, there is an evil, and to that end, that even the ultimate good has an ultimate darkness lieing in its shadow.<br />This film, based on the novel by William Peter Blatty, and directed by William Friedkin, is the story of two priests and a family living in Georgetown University, just outside Washington D.C.  Blatty, who wrote the novel and screenplay, based the story of a child's possession by the devil on actual events that he had read about many years before writing the Exorcist.  <br />The story begins with an elderly priest, Father Merrin, who is working as a missionary in Iraq.  A former exorcist, Merrin is confronted by a vision of the demon and is given a premonition of events that will unfold later.<br />The story continues in counterpoint, introducing us to Father Damien Karras, a young, Italian priest whose mother is dieing of poverty.  A student at Georgetown University, and the psychiatrist on the staff of Saint Michaels, Karras's faith is shaken when his mother dies while in the custody of a sanitarium for the poor and impoverished.<br />The other half of this counterpoint is the story of Regan, daughter of movie-star Chris MacNeil, who is at Georgetown University filming a student-rights movie.  They rent a home on the campus, and while they live there, Regan begins to refer to an invisible friend who she refers to as &quot;Captain Howdy&quot;.  As the story progresses, Regans disposition begins to change.  She starts complaining of headaches, and has outbursts that are completely uncharacteristic of her, and before long, all that see her begin to believe she is either medically insane, or possessed.<br />Chris MacNeil implores the help of Father Karras to aid her in exorcising her daughter.  Uncertain what to do, Karras turns to the head of his order and seeks the assistance of Merrin, who has since returned from Iraq.<br />The story works on a number of levels.  The visual experience of the film is horrifying, as Regan is transformed from an innocent little girl into the demon that possesses her.  The film is dark, graphic and often very disturbing in its imagery.  But what makes this film far more frightening than the visual images is the psychological effect it has on its viewer.  This movie transcends the screen, and plays out like a literary work, giving incredible depth to each of its characters, making them very believable and easy to relate to.  <br />By the end of the story, the movie examines everything from the power of faith, to the power of darkness, and leave the viewer with an experience that will effect them to their very soul.<br />The DVD edition of this film contains many extras, including interviews with the director of the film and the author of the original novel (who himself was a Georgetown student).  It also contains footage that has never been seen in earlier releases of this work.  The film is controversal, and still one of the most disturbing pieces of all time.  It is an important film, and not one to be taken lightly.  <br />Scott Kolecki
B0000AQZYM|5.0|I still remember going to the theaters with my dad when I was 7 and sitting on his lap and giggling at toy story while a snow storm raged outside. With their 5th installment of their timeless saga and \\"The Incredibles\\" coming next year, Pixar just seems to be getting better and better! I'm almost 15 now and I was laughing at some of the same jokes as my little sister that saw it with me. It's really cute and amusing. The characters are REALLY lovable and you feel really empathetic towards them. It's also really suspenseful and the animation is remarkable! Other reviewers have said they didn't like the short, but I thought it was really creative and well-done considering it was done over a decade ago! Nemo is the story of a fish trying to prove himself to his overprotective dad and finding out the hard way that you always pay the price for stepping out of line when he's sent off to live in a dentist's office in Sydney. There, he meets possibly the most eccentric characters you'll see in a Pixar film. They let him join their ranks as they desperately try to hatch an escape plan before the dentist gives the little fish to his niece who is known for not being so nice to her fish... (x_x) Meanwhile, his freaked out father scours the ocean floor with a dim-witted fish named Dory, desperately trying to secure info on his whereabouts while running into surfer turtles, organized sharks, and some other \\"interesting\\" fishy fellas. The ending will leave you with a warm feeling inside and it's meant to be shared with the whole family. I highly recommend it for any Pixar fans or any movie-goers at all. This is one of those films that belongs in your collection.

B000002UA0|5.0|I put this Floyd CD into my player. By the time Track 3 started, wonderful flashes and flushes of repeating hot and cold flashed through my mind. Once my girlfriend's 10 foot head got out of my view, and after she saw that I was doing fine, I saw my apartment like it was a completely different world. First thing I looked at was the acoustic ceiling and it appeared of wonderful dots of pastel green and pastel maroon on a white background. The dots were in constant motion but mainly moving medium speed to slower speed while occasionally temporarily stopping while becoming fuzzy then moving again (the effect of flowing syrup down a slope, then changing the slope another direction). Occasionally the colored dots would chase each other, playing cat and mouse and on that note I went into around a 5 minute visually mental trip of cats and mice chasing each other. After I came back from the 'mental chase' trip I looked at the ceiling again, this time all the dots aligned themselves into splendid designs looking exactly like the curly designs found on Indian and Arabian carpets. The patterns were in constant motion but still symmetrical to the point of perfectly making an entire pattern instead of a pile of random dots occasionally aligning up. What was real fun was standing up and getting closer to the ceiling and watching the dots not scatter but remain in the same changing but symmetric shape. All the songs on the album brought to reality that this vintage Pink Floyd, especially when concentrating on Syd's voice and guitar, doesn't just knock your eyes out of whack or anything similar, but truly does alter one's perception to the point of making real audibly, mentally, emotionally and visually things that truly do not exist except in one's mind.<br />Syd Barrett is God.

0385504209|5.0|Ok- first off... I really did enjoy this book. However, now that I have read 3 of Brown's novels, I have noticed a certain formula that Dan Brown uses.<br />1- Use the word &quot;Indredulous&quot; as often as possible.<br />2- The bad guy MUST be known by a term/phrase instead of a name.<br />3- The bad guy is double crossing the good guys... and you are NOT supposed to suspect this.<br />4- The novel must take place in the course of one day.<br />5- Your hero must wake-up and not have a clue that he will spend his entire day many miles away from home, while being chased by bad guys.<br />6- All good guys must be experts at something very arcane.<br />7- The ending must be weak.<br />If you follow these steps you too can write a Dan Brown novel. ORRRR you can use this formula to figure out the book you are currently reading after about 100 pages.<br />This is clearly a case of diminishing returns. One book is Awesome, two is fun, but by the third... you are ready to turn on the television.<br />My suggestion- read the Da Vinci Code (However, remember it is still &quot;fiction&quot; and despite the authors claims- some of his facts are seriously flawed- for instance - &quot;The Gosphel of Mary&quot; is hardly widely accepted as legitimate).<br />&quot;The Da Vinci Code&quot; is extremely face paced, and quite thought provoking. It challenged me to do a little research into the foundation of my beliefs (However, it did not change my beliefs... I found that my views on religon are on much sounder ground that the author's supposed &quot;research&quot;). Enjoy...
B00004BZ0N|5.0|This is an amazing album from an amazing group.  The Clash is really much more than some people realize.  It's not fair to call them punk first of all, because they're musical styles range from hard rock to ska to even reggae.  Also, this album was created in 1979- that was still in the Zeppelin days!  This was an album unlike any other in a time where music seemed less like a passion and more like a business.  All together this album squeezes 19 songs on your compact disk, ranging from the 1:40 &quot;Kola Kola&quot; to the 5:00+ &quot;Revolution rock.&quot; Some highlights of the album include &quot;London Calling,&quot; a good opener and basically lays out The Clash's game plan.  &quot;Rudy Can't Fail&quot; &quot;Revolution Rock&quot; and &quot;Wrong 'em Boyo&quot; are excellent ska songs while &quot;The Guns of Brixton&quot; experiments with some reggae and &quot;Death Or Glory,&quot; &quot;I'm Not Down,&quot; and &quot;Clampdown&quot; just plain rock.  I recommend this album to anyone who wants to try something new; the Clash will satisfy anyone's musical tastes.  As a die-hard classic rocker, I was a little skeptical at first, but this has become one of my all time favorites...
0671027387|3.0|Ok- first off... I really did enjoy this book. However, now that I have read 3 of Brown's novels, I have noticed a certain formula that Dan Brown uses.<br />1- Use the word \\"Indredulous\\" as often as possible.<br />2- The bad guy MUST be known by a term/phrase instead of a name.<br />3- The bad guy is double crossing the good guys... and you are NOT supposed to suspect this.<br />4- The novel must take place in the course of one day.<br />5- Your hero must wake-up and not have a clue that he will spend his entire day many miles away from home, while being chased by bad guys.<br />6- All good guys must be experts at something very arcane.<br />7- The ending must be weak.<br />If you follow these steps you too can write a Dan Brown novel. ORRRR you can use this formula to figure out the book you are currently reading after about 100 pages.<br />This is clearly a case of diminishing returns. One book is Awesome, two is fun, but by the third... you are ready to turn on the television.<br /><br />This is the weakest of the three novels that I have read by Brown (the others being Da Vinci Code, Angels and Demons). The plot had more flaws, and the ending was even weaker than his other books. However, it was the third of the three, so using the FORMULA I pretty much had it figured out. Let me put it this way- this is the most forgettable of the three that I have read.<br />My suggestion- read the Da Vinci Code (However, remember it is still \\"fiction\\" and despite the authors claims- some of his facts are seriously flawed- for instance - \\"The Gospel of Mary\\" is hardly widely accepted as legitimate).
B00008OWZC|5.0|This album is 100% live and that's the way it should be.  Led Zeppelin was not meant to be heard on professionally mixed tracks.  They were meant to be heard raw and reckless, which is basically what their music as all about.  With this album, you can also really appreciate the sort of telepathy that seemed to exist between them (nearly half of the music was improvised.)  Do you think they planned on busting into &quot;Mary Lou&quot; in the middle of &quot;Whole Lotta Love?&quot;  That is what makes Led Zeppelin so great.  Not many bands can say they sound 10 times better live than on their albums.  Not to mention Jimmy Page's wild solos.  This is a must-have for anyone who thinks stairway was decent on Zeppelin IV. (wait till you hear the live version)  Any Zeppelin fan will love disk one, but disks two and three are only for those who have the patience and the appreciation for the 20 minute masterpieces, &quot;Dazed and Confused&quot; and &quot;Whole Lotta Love&quot;

A great big thank you to you, Stephen!  He is thoroughly humble... as I said, I didn't even like him, could never imagine liking him... until I read this book... and, to triple repeat myself... it is THE BEST!  If you want to be a writer... this IS the book to have... not a book to check out of the library... one to own and underline and re-read and cherish... an utter inspiration.  When I read his chapter on mental telepathy and writing... I had to put the book down for a day just to let that sink in... he says that we aren't even in the same place, not even the same year, and yet he can communicate something clearly... telepathically send you a picture with writing... and he is right... powerful stuff, this writing business!  Buy it!
B000001ESP|5.0|Many People conceder this to be the best album Rush ever made, and for good reason none of the tracks are bad or weak or are lacking in any way. But many also conceder this to be to comercial. I am in the middle, while I agree that this and Permanant Waves were both very commercial albums, I still love them.<br />Rush is a very talented band and the comes across loud and clear on Moving Pictures. The song writing is great, though its not as good as on 2112 it is still very good. Each song is about something, and the music to each song tells a story if you listen carefully. There are no big elaberate guitar solos or anything like thats from Alex Lifeson but his playing is still very good and skilled here. Geddys bass was never better, and Neils drumming is over the top as always! 'Tom Sawyer' 'Limelight' and 'Red Barcetta' are all here and all went on to be big hit singles. But Moving Pictures is more then that the lesser known tracks are amazing as well. For example 'The Camras Eye' and 'YYZ' are both Rush classics. So you see there is really nothing bad with this album, as long as you dont mind really good music played by extremly skilled players. I dont know wether Rush is a Prog band or a hard rock band but either way they rock harder and better then most bands did back at that this came out!

This is concederd a concept album but I really cant see why, because most concept albums are not this good. I would recomend this to new and old fans of Rush because it gives a good since of what the band was really about!

0385484518|5.0|This book is wonderful.  I am very glad that I was able to read it.  Morrie Schwartz was an exceptional man that even though I could not meet him, I feel very close to him thanks to the openness he shared with Albom.  Morrie was dying, and was not afraid to admit it.  He decided to help others, as he had done his whole life through teaching, one last time.  This book teaches us about many life lessons that we all know that we should do, be kind to one another, always say I love you, and hugs are wonderful tools of communication.  I would recommend this book for anyone who needs a new reason to live.  That reason is purely for the joy of loving humanity and those around you.
B00006RU5B|4.0|Combining the awesome vocals of Chris Cornell and the instrumentals from one of the best hard rock bands of all time turns out to be a very entertaining move.  This new band has a lot to offer I believe.  It is clear when listening that though the instrumentals often kick it up to their rage days on many songs, they also often make a compromise to slow themselves down, something that is no less moving.  Conversely, Cornell seems to be changing his style occasionally just slightly in the direction of a &quot;RATM&quot; style.  I don't know much about Soundgarden (though I sure want to after hearing this cd), but I do know that Cornell has a great voice and this band has already made some great music.  Personal favorites, besides the overplayed &quot;Like a Stone&quot;, are &quot;show me how to live&quot;, &quot;set it off&quot;, &quot;What you are&quot;, &quot;exploder&quot; and &quot;I am the Highway&quot;.  Though many of these songs take a while to get into because they're a little slower than songs like &quot;cochise&quot;, they will certainly always be good songs to just sit down and relish in.

After this book, I sat there and cried... it made me feel so different, my outlook on life was completely changed. I know everyone can't feel that way about certain books, but this book did. I read 'The Perks of being a Wallflower' in such a short time, but I felt like I was living the book. After reading the book, I listened to The Smiths' song &quot;Asleep.&quot; I had never felt so happy and sad at the same time. This book is a definite read.. I reccomend it to anyone and everyone.
